questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with fever and weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Which of the following signifies a bad prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the bone marrow histology suggest a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), where peripheral blast counts of >100,000 is a poor prognostic factor.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphomas (ALL) are neoplasms composed of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells referred to as lymphoblasts. About 85% are B-cell ALLs which present as childhood leukemias and T-ALLs are usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement.

Clinical Features:

  • Abrupt stormy onset within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.
  • Symptoms related to depression of marrow function include anemia and fever,
  • Secondary infections due to neutropenia and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
  • Mass effects caused by neoplastic infiltration.
  • Bone pain resulting from marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly
  • Testicular enlargement
  • Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies

Genetic diseases like Bloom syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and ataxia-telangiectasia predisposes to ALL.

Histopathology of ALL:

  • The marrow is hypercellular and packed with lymphoblasts. These cells replace the normal marrow.
  • Lymphoblasts have scant cytoplasm with no granulations. They are myeloperoxidase negative and contain PAS-positive cytoplasmic material.
  • The tumor cells have a basophilic cytoplasm. The nuclei of these cells are larger than the small lymphocytes. The nucleoli are usually small. The nuclear chromatin is delicate and finely stippled, and nucleoli are small and demarcated by a rim of condensed chromatin. The nuclear membrane is deeply subdivided and gives a convoluted appearance.
  • The macrophages engulfing the apoptotic tumor cells might give it a starry sky appearance as in other rapidly growing tumors.

Cytogenetics and immunophenotype:

  • Majority of the cells express TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase), a specialized DNA polymerase that is expressed only in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.
  • Immature B-ALLs do not express CD10. Late pre-B-ALLs express CD10, CD19, and CD20
  • T-ALLs are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7.
  • The more immature tumors are usually negative for CD3, CD4, and CD8, but late pre–T-cell tumors are positive for these markers.

Factors associated with a worse prognosis:

  • Age younger than 2 years
  • Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
  • Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000, which probably reflects a high tumor burden.

Factors associated with good prognosis:

  • Age between 2 and 10 years
  • A low white cell count
  • Hyperdiploidy
  • Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, and 10
  • Presence of t(12;21)

questions.text: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe pruritus and yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL and serum transaminase levels were mildly elevated. A biopsy of the liver would most likely show?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy which is caused due to defective transport of bilirubin from the hepatocytes into the biliary canaliculi as depicted in the third histopathological slide.  Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease that may occur later in pregnancy. It is characterized by intense pruritus, which is worse on palms and soles, and icterus. The key laboratory findings include increased serum bile acid levels, elevated transaminases, and elevated direct and total bilirubin serum concentrations.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis. Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial haemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.

Other slides:

Slide 1: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. Pathological features include emperipolesis, interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis and rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration. Below is a histology slide depicting the same.

Slide 2: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells forming trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver.

Image below: Histology of hepatoblastoma showing proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial type cells.

Slide 4: Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism; however, it may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys. The below image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis (fatty change) along with intraparenchymal cholestasis . The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on H&E staining.

questions.text: A young man presents with chest pain and breathlessness. Work-up revealed ventricular dilatation and a low ejection fraction on echo. He gives a history of heart disease in the family. Which of the following cardiac histological findings can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young man presenting with chest pain and breathlessness and an echo showing ventricular dilatation with a low ejection fraction, along with a positive family history, is suggestive of familial dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). Cardiac histology, in this case, would reveal ninja-star nuclei in myocytes.

Familial DCM is most commonly associated with truncation mutation of the TTN gene, which codes for the intra-sarcomeric protein titin. The genetic forms follow the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with variable penetrance. Histological examinations of cardiac myocytes may reveal nuclei that are hyperchromatic and highly distorted, resembling ninja stars (as shown below).

DCM is characterized by both morphological and functional progressive dilatation of the heart along with systolic dysfunction. It results in the gradual development of congestive heart failure with clinical features of dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, and peripheral pitting edema.

Other options:

Option A: Contraction band necrosis can be seen in reperfusion injury following myocardial infarction. It is also a histological feature observed in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Histology reveals irreversibly injured myocytes and intensely eosinophilic bands of hypercontracted sarcomeres, as depicted below.

 

Option C: Haphazard disarray of myofibrils is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction. Histological findings of myofiber disarray is shown below. 

 

Option D: Hyaline, amorphous eosinophilic deposits on histology are associated with cardiac amyloidosis. It results in restrictive cardiomyopathy with stiffened myocardial walls causing diastolic dysfunction. Transthyretin is the major component of cardiac amyloid deposits. Histological findings of cardiac amyloidosis are shown below.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. Radiological investigations revealed a tumor arising from a major bronchus. Histopathology shows the following image depicting small, basophillic cells with dense chromatin. Which of the following is associated with this tumor?
  1. Hypercalcemia
  2. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)
  3. Cushing's syndrome
  4. Cerebellar degeneration
questions.solution:
Histopathology shows small cells with a salt-and-pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls. The given clinical history and histology image suggest a diagnosis of small-cell lung cancer (SCLC). Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), Cushing's syndrome, and cerebellar degeneration are paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small-cell lung cancer.

Some cancer patients develop signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the location of the cancer or its cells of origin. These are called paraneoplastic syndromes. Paraneoplastic syndromes are important to identify since they might be the first presenting feature of an occult tumor, they might present similar to metastasis of the tumor and can be lethal.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton- Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness
  • peripheral neuropathy
  • Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration.
Adenocarcinoma 
  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  •  Clubbing

questions.text: A patient suffering from a dermatological condition undergoes a skin biopsy. The histological section of the skin taken from a patient is shown in the image given below. What is the patient most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows papillary tip microabscesses, which are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis.

Papillary tip microabscesses are mixed microabscesses that contain neutrophils and some eosinophils in the tips of the dermal papillae. They are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis and bullous eruptions like epidermolysis bullosa and the bullous form of lupus erythematosus.

The image given below shows papillary tip microabscesses.

Other options:

Option B: Psoriasis is characterized by Munro's microabscesses, which are neutrophilic microabscesses that are found in the stratum corneum. They are seen along with features of irregular epidermal thickening and parakeratosis.

The image given below shows epidermal hyperplasia with loss of the granular cell layer, parakeratosis, and Munro’s microabscesses suggestive of psoriasis.

Option C: Histology of pemphigus vulgaris shows a suprabasal split of the epidermis with a characteristic row of tombstone appearance as seen below.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides is characterized by Pautrier's microabscesses, which are intraepidermal lymphocytic microabscesses in the absence of marked spongiosis. The cells within the epidermis may show nuclear hyperchromatism or atypia.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in mycosis fungoides.

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

questions.text: During histology class, you are asked to identify the various epithelia and their locations in the body. Which of the following parts of the urethra is lined by the epithelium shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium, which is identified by the variations in the cell layers: the deepest cell layer is columnar, the middle is made of polyhedral cells, and, lastly, the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped. Transitional epithelium lines the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra (not the membranous urethra).  

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium.  

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched, it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with symptoms of pain, itching and bloody discharge from the right nipple. On examination, there is a crusted lesion that is erythematous and thickened with irregular borders, involving the nipple and areola. A full-thickness wedge biopsy of the lesion was done and the finding is shown in the image below. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Paget's disease of the nipple.

The histologic image shows the presence of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells called Paget cells. They occur singly or in small groups within the epidermis of the nipple.

Paget's disease is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It is an uncommon presentation of breast carcinoma affecting women between 50 and 60 years of age.

Patients may initially have pain, burning, and pruritus of the nipple. On examination, a crusted lesion with irregular borders or a scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion that begins over the nipple and spreads to the surrounding areola is seen. This may be accompanied by a bloody discharge. Paget's disease is usually unilateral and nipple retraction is a rare finding but may occur with advanced disease.

A bilateral breast examination should be performed. Nipple scrape cytology can accurately diagnose Paget's disease, but the diagnosis is usually established by a full-thickness wedge or punch biopsy of the nipple. 

The histologic hallmark of the disease is the presence of Paget cells. The cells are often large and the cytoplasm is pale to clear, and the nuclei are usually high-grade with prominent nucleoli. 

Management is based on the stage of the tumor and prognostic factors. Simple mastectomy and breast-conserving treatment (BCT) are two of the most common procedures used in the surgical management of the tumour. Sentinel lymph node biopsy should also be done to look for axillary lymph node involvement.

Other options:

Option A: Acute mastitis is usually seen in lactating women, with common etiological factors being inadequate milk sucking by the infant, milk expression causing stasis, and infection from the mouth of the infant. Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly implicated organism. The affected breast or a segment of it shows the classical signs of acute inflammation which include redness, swelling, and pain. 

Option C: Eczema of the nipples is a rare condition and is often bilateral. It occurs in the younger age group and is also associated with eczema elsewhere over the body. It frequently begins in the areola and may then involve the nipple while Paget's disease originates on the nipple and secondarily involves the areola.

Option D: Duct papillomas are polyploid lesions of epithelial-lined breast ducts. They are often located close to the areola, but when located close to the nipple, blood-stained nipple discharge can be present. They are not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. On histology, there is a fibrovascular mass from the wall of the duct. The papillae arborize in the lumen as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent blood in the urine and pain in the left flank. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, the patient appears weak and has a palpable mass in the left flank. CT shows a renal tumor. A radical nephrectomy was performed and the histology of the specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and histology specimen showing round or polygonal tumor cells with clear cytoplasm is suggestive of clear cell carcinoma. 

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common renal cell carcinoma. The growth pattern of clear cell carcinomas varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular. Cells are round or polygonal in shape. The cytoplasm is clear or granular and it contains glycogen and lipid.

Clear cell carcinoma mostly arises from the proximal tubular epithelium. It is associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3. The VHL gene (tumor suppressor gene) is located on chromosome 3p.

Clear cell carcinomas are usually single and unilateral. They are spherical masses that vary in size. Composed of yellow-colored tissue that distorts the renal outline. The yellow color is due to the accumulation of lipids in tumor cells.

The most common risk factors of renal cell carcinoma are tobacco usage, obesity, hypertension, and unopposed estrogen therapy. 

Other options:

Option A- Chromophobe carcinoma arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Tumor cells have pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with a halo around the nucleus and prominent cell membranes as shown below.

Option B- Papillary carcinoma arises from distal convoluted tubules. They can be multifocal and bilateral. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities associated are trisomies 7, 17 and loss of Y. Tumor cells are cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formation with psammoma bodies as shown below.

Option D- Collecting duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the collecting duct cells in the medulla. They show irregular channels lined by atypical epithelium with a hobnail pattern as shown below.

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: Given below is the histological structure of an endocrine gland. The blood supply to this gland arises from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the histology of the parathyroid gland. It is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery which is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. 

It can be identified by the presence of acidophilic and principal cells. The principal cells have pale staining cytoplasm while the acidophilic cells are larger than principal cells and have acidophilic cytoplasm. The principal cells produce parathormone. The function of the oxyphil cells is unknown. 

Other options:

Option B- External carotid artery gives a branch called the superior thyroid artery which supplies thyroid gland. The thyroid gland can be identified by the presence of epithelium-lined thyroid follicles. The center of each follicle has a lightly staining colloid. 

Below image shows thyroid gland

 

Option C- The internal carotid artery supplies the pituitary gland via hypophyseal arteries. Section of the pituitary gland can be identified by the presence of pars distalis, pars tuberalis, and pars intermedia. Pars distalis contains chromophils having hormones stored in cytoplasmic granules. Pars tuberalis contains gonadotrophs and pars intermedia is a region between pars distalis and pars nervosa.

Below image shows pituitary gland

 

Option D- Superior mesenteric artery supplies pancreas. Pancreas can be identified by the presence of islets. The islet cells are polygonal or rounded, and more lightly stained than the surrounding acinar cells.

Below image shows pancreas

questions.text: An autopsy of a 38-year-old male patient who died of cardiac failure showed the following histopathological image of the endocardium. Which of the following best describes the form of vegetation found in this condition?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing Anitschkow cells and Aschoff bodies are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). It is associated with small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

Image: Histology of a rheumatic fever patient showing Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the forearm which appeared 7 months back. New lesions have appeared on the other arm after abrasions at the same site. A skin biopsy done to confirm the diagnosis shows the following histology. What is the structure marked?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lichen planus. The structure marked in the histopathological image of lichen planus is civatte bodies.

Civatte bodies/Colloid bodies are damaged basal keratinocytes that have undergone apoptosis, consist largely of keratin intermediate filaments, and are almost always covered with immunoglobulins. They are found particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. They are usually seen in lichenoid dermatosis.

Lichen planus is the most typical lichenoid dermatosis. It is characterized by idiopathic inflammation of skin and mucosal tissues. It has mostly a chronic course with frequent relapses.

Lichen Planus manifests as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques - which are the 6Ps of lichen planus. It also exhibits Wickham striae (thin white lacy lines on the lesion), Koebner phenomenon (new lesions at sites of skin trauma).

Histopathology of lichen planus typically shows interface dermatitis, saw toothing, Max Joseph’s space, Civatte or colloid bodies.

The following image shows the histology of Lichen planus with loss of rete ridges, loss of stratum basale, and interface dermatitis.

The following image shows lesions characteristic of lichen planus - Pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques:

Squamous cell carcinoma may arise from mucosal and paramucosal lichen planus.

Other options :

Option A: Schaumann bodies are seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are laminated concretions composed of calcium and protein

Option B: Asteroid bodies are seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are stellate inclusions within giant cells.

Option C: Donovan bodies are characteristic of in granuloma inguinale (also called donovanosis). They are due to macrophages encapsulating Klebsiella granulomatis coccobacilli.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced (11;19) (q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a well-circumscribed, soft mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. On examination, the axillary lymph nodes are enlarged. Her paternal aunt and sister also had a history of breast carcinoma in the same age group. Molecular examination revealed the tumor to be triple-negative. Biopsy shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the breast which is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. The histopathology shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing border.

Medullary carcinoma is a less common type of breast carcinoma and is a common type seen in BRCA1 mutation. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative. It is softer than other carcinomas due to minimal desmoplasia. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage.

ER-negative and HER2-negative (triple-negative or “basal-like”) carcinomas can be characterized by genomic instability (denoted by multiple chromosomal changes), a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (like basal keratins).

Histopathology consists of:

  • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
  • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation
  • Solid, syncytium-like sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, which compose more than 75% of the tumor mass
  • Frequent mitotic figures
  • A pushing (non infiltrative) border

Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. 

It has a better survival rate than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

 

Option C: Lobular carcinoma of the breast : The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets. Tubule formation is absent in this subtype. Single line of cells are seen lining the normal duct (bottom right of the image) which is the characteristic Indian file/ Single file appearance.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric and presents as hard irregular masses
  • It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia
  • It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma. 

 

Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form signet ring appearance.

questions.text: A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The histological features shown in the image below are seen in:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the histology of tonsils with non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and lymphoid nodules in the center.

The tonsil consists of lymphoid nodules, which are surrounded by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium on its oropharyngeal surface. The epithelium dips into the substance of the gland and forms tonsillar crypts.

The following image shows the histology of the tonsils:

 

Histology of thymus (option A):

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue. 

Each lobule is made up of an outer darker staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains pink rounded masses called Hassell's corpuscles.

 

Structure of a lymph node (option B):

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:

 

Structure of spleen (Option D):

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

Microscopic features of the spleen:

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.

Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue:

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: What is the most common genetic alteration of this thyroid tumor?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of empty nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei which is characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The most common is the BRAF V600E mutation.

BRAF V600E mutation is also seen in

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Colon adenocarcinoma
  • Melanoma

Other chromosomal rearrangements in papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • RET-PTC fusion (option A) - seen in sporadic papillary cancers; uncommon
  • NTRK1 mutation

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:

  • Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
  • Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei -  
    • Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin
    • They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion 


Other options:

Option C: p53 mutation is seen in anaplastic thyroid cancer. 

Option D: RAS mutation is seen in follicular thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady presents with symmetric and proximal muscle weakness for the past few weeks. She has no history of dysphagia or dysarthria and no cutaneous lesions were seen on examination. On evaluating her further, creatinine kinase levels were elevated and muscle biopsy shows the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with elevated levels of creatinine kinase (CK) and muscle biopsy showing non-specific inflammatory cells in endomysial locations is suggest the most likely diagnosis to be polymyositis.

Polymyositis is one of the inflammatory myopathies characterized by symmetric and proximal muscle weakness. This weakness usually worsens over several weeks to months. 

It is more common in women. Most patients improve with immunotherapies, but they require lifelong treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Inclusion body myositis is characterized by asymmetric weakness of wrist and finger flexors in arms and quadriceps in legs. Dysphagia is also commonly seen. It is common in adults >50 years of age. CK levels are normal or slightly elevated. Antibodies against 5' nucleotidase are seen in the blood. 

Option C: Dermatomyositis (DM) characterized by symmetrical and proximal muscle weakness. The dermatological manifestations of DM include: 

  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of the eyelid with periorbital edema
  • Gottron sign - erythematous rash over joints
  • Gottron papules - raised erythematous rash over knuckles
  • V rash - over sun-exposed areas 

It can present in adults as well as children. It has a high risk for malignancies. CK levels can be normal or elevated. Histology shows perifascicular atrophy and perivascular inflammatory infiltrates. 

The images below show: Heliotrope rash, Gottron papules and V rash respectively. 

Option D: Necrotising autoimmune myopathy is characterized by acute onset of symmetric and proximal muscle weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and myalgia. It is associated with an underlying connective tissue disorder or cancer. CK levels are markedly elevated. Histology shows multifocal necrotic and regenerating muscle fibers with a paucity of inflammatory cells.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presents with epigastric pain and anorexia. Urea breath test is positive for the patient. Endoscopy shows thickening of the stomach wall. A biopsy is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with anorexia and epigastric pain with a positive urea breath test (indicating H. pylori infection) and the slide showing lymphoepithelial lesions suggest a diagnosis of gastric MALToma. 

Extranodal marginal B-cell lymphomas usually arise at the sites of chronic inflammation. Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) is not present in the normal stomach but can be induced, typically as a result of chronic gastritis. H. pylori infection is the most common inducing factor of MALT and is often found in association with MALTomas. The presenting complaints are similar to adenocarcinoma and include abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and anorexia.

Histologically, MALTomas show dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create lymphoepithelial lesions. MALTomas express B-cell markers like CD19 and CD20, but not CD5 or CD10. 25% of the cases are positive for CD43. Eradication of H. pylori with antibiotics has shown to be an effective therapy for MALToma. Surgical resection has no role in the treatment unless there has been some complication like perforation or uncontrollable bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy of the stomach. The intestinal-type of adenocarcinoma forms bulky masses. They are composed of columnar cells which form gland-like structures in a desmoplastic stroma, as shown in the image below.

 

The diffusely infiltrative type of gastric adenocarcinoma can be recognized by the presence of signet ring cells and no gland formation as shown below. Signet ring cells have a large, central vacuole filled with mucin, and the nucleus is seen as a thin crescent rim at the periphery.

 

Option B: Autoimmune gastritis is characterized by damage to oxyntic cells within the body and the fundus of the stomach. The inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells. In contrast to H. pylori-associated gastritis where the inflammation is limited to lamina propria, the inflammation in autoimmune gastritis goes deeper and is centered on the gastric glands. 

Option D: Gastrointestinal tumor (GIST) is a mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen. Most GISTs have a gain of function mutation in KIT. The microscopic appearance of GIST consists of thin elongated cells (spindle cell type) as shown in the image below, or plumper, epithelial-appearing cells (epithelioid type). Most commonly an admixture of the two is seen.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with stiffness and weakness of limbs which rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted where the histology of the brain parenchyma is as shown below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive condition
Brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing a 4-month-old baby with motor signs like stiffness and weakness with rapid progression and histology of brain showing characteristic globoid cells is suggestive of Krabbe disease where peripheral nerves are equally affected.

Krabbe's disease :

Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy. It is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy resulting from a deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase, the enzyme required for the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosylsphingosine, a compound toxic to both oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness Survival beyond the age of 2 years is uncommon. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

A unique and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages (globoid cells) in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is found to have elevated levels of liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. The gene responsible for this condition is present on which chromosome?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. α1AT deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding. The liver is affected due to the accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes and presents as chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or hepatocellular carcinoma. Liver biopsy shows round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. 

Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase, causing panacinar emphysema. This occurs at an earlier age and is of greater severity if the individual smokes. In this type, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells).
